awd_titl_txt: Operations of VERITAS in the Epoch 2011 to 2014
awd_abstract_narration:
The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS) began full-scale operations in September 2007 and completed a telescope upgrade in the summer of 2012.  This award funds ongoing maintenance and operation of both the telescopes and the array facility over a 3-year period.  VERITAS seeks to both identify new sources of Very High Energy (VHE: E >100 Gigaelectron-volt) gamma rays, and to perform in-depth studies of the known sources to better understand their underlying fundamental processes.  The primary targets of VERITAS Galactic observations are supernova remnants, pulsars, binary systems, and known VHE sources whose classification is currently unknown. The extragalactic targets observed by VERITAS include active galactic nuclei, radio galaxies, starburst galaxies, galaxy clusters and gamma-ray bursts.  In addition, Local Group galaxies, dwarf galaxies and globular clusters are targets of VERITAS observations focused on the indirect detection of cold dark matter.  VERITAS is currently the most-sensitive VHE gamma-ray observatory in the world.  After 6-years of operation, the experiment is well-understood and promised performance metrics of the experiment (e.g. total data yield and data quality) are achieved or surpassed.  Continued operations of VERITAS for this funding cycle are expected to result in new gamma-ray science.  

Broader Impact and Outreach:  The VERITAS collaboration is involved in public engagement as an important element of its research program.  The Adler Planetarium and the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory Visitors Center at the VERITAS site coordinate activities, websites and public displays to promote VERITAS science to the public, other educators, museum professionals and the wider community.  VERITAS scientists provide education and public outreach experiences in the form of multimedia products, public presentations and activities such as classroom visits, an annual public lecture series, "star parties" at the observatory, and tours of the experiment.

por.por_cntn:
VERITAS is the world’s most-sensitive very-high-energy (VHE; E > 100 GeV) gamma-ray observatory, and is located in southern Arizona.  This award from the NSF partially supported the operations of the VERITAS telescope array and the array facility for the purposes of astrophysical research from 2013-2017.  The support covered the project’s seventh through tenth season of operation.  VERITAS remains operational, the experiment is in excellent condition and support is identified to operate the facility through at least 2019.
    A recent external review concluded the VERITAS collaboration “pioneered the field of ground-based gamma-ray astronomy and is one of three leading experiments at this time.  It is a key experiment in a triad, with Fermi and HAWC, allowing the US to decisively lead the field of gamma-ray astronomy”.   The scientific operation of VERITAS was highly successful during the award.  The VERITAS collaboration has reported the detection of 60 astrophysical sources of VHE gamma rays, belonging to ~8 different source classes.  The VERITAS catalog increased by ~20% during the award period, and overall it now represents about one-third of the entire VHE catalog.   All VERITAS results are published in high-impact factor, peer-reviewed journals.  The VERITAS collaboration has published 99 refereed journal articles and has produced 56 PhD theses. Forty-three of these articles appeared, and twenty-three of these theses were completed, during the award period.  This publication rate compares favorably to other VHE experiments.  While the science program addressed a number of important topics in astrophysics, one particular science highlight involves the unexpected detection of VHE gamma-rays from a galaxy located more than halfway across the universe.  This unique detection was the first detection of large-scale VHE emission from an extragalactic source, and enabled strong single-source constraints for cosmology.  Significant science remains to be completed by VERITAS, including our legacy observing program.  Observing time at VERITAS remains oversubscribed and approximately 50 VERITAS journal articles are in preparation, with five near submission. The training mission of VERITAS also remains strong as 40% of the collaboration members are students.
    During the award period, VERITAS operations also could only be described as highly successful.  External reviews held during the award period commented on “impressive levels of operational efficiency and expanded uptime of the telescopes” and noted “the project is extremely well managed”.  Another report noted VERITAS “is a mature experiment with a well-developed maintenance and operation plan that has constantly delivered a stream of quality science data with high efficiency”.  Specifically, an average of 1310 h of data were taken over the four seasons covered by this award, exceeding the project requirements of more than 900 h per year.  In addition, all performance metrics for these data were met and often exceeded and no event rendered any significant quantity of data unusable.  Significant cost-cutting measures were also developed and tested, enabling future VERITAS operations to proceed with more than 20% reduced budget.
        Throughout this award the VERITAS collaboration continued its strong commitment to enabling public understanding of science as an outcome of its research.  At the VERITAS site itself, the F.L. Whipple Observatory (FLWO) Visitor’s Center continued to coordinate many ongoing activities to promote VERITAS science to the public and the wider community.  Here displays, exhibits and videos presented astronomy and astrophysics relevant to VERITAS.  VERITAS Project Office (VPO) scientists also delivered public lectures and participated in the extensive community outreach program at FLWO.  This included providing formal & informal tours of the VERITAS site for journalists, authors, astronomy clubs, and youth groups.  VPO scientists also hosted star parties, participated in science fairs, and visited school classrooms.  A public website (http://veritas.sao.arizona.edu) operated by the VPO provided a description of the VERITAS project and related science. All refereed VERITAS publications and PhD theses are also linked to this page, along with a brief description of each result. A VERITAS Facebook page and Twitter feed are also active, and a YouTube channel contains video content from VERITAS scientists.  Over the course of the award we also enabled may unique outreach experiences; one of our more recent endeavors was the VERITAS Muon Hunter partnership with the Zooniverse project.  Here crowd-sourcing was used to test methods for the classification of VERITAS background (muon) images.  Over 5000 volunteers participated in a trial, and over 2 million images were classified.
    The VERITAS collaboration is grateful for the support of the U.S. National Science Foundation which makes its research possible.
